required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Trial of Cannabidiol (CBD; GWP42003-P) for Infantile Spasms (GWPCARE7)
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Trial to Investigate the Efficacy and Safety of Cannabidiol (CBD; GWP42003-P) in Infants With Infantile Spasms Following an Initial Open-label Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock: This trial consists of 3 parts: a pilot safety phase, a pivotal randomized controlled phase, and an open-label extension phase. The pilot phase only will be described in this record. 2 cohorts of 5 participants will be enrolled sequentially. All participants will receive GWP42003-P.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Severe Treatment-emergent Adverse Events (TEAEs)
primary_outcome.time_frame: From signing of informed consent up to Day 15
primary_outcome.description: TEAEs are defined as all adverse events not present prior to the first investigational medicinal product (IMP) or placebo administration or any event already present that worsened in severity or frequency following IMP.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Any Low or High Hematology Laboratory Parameter Value
Number of Participants With Any Low or High Biochemistry Laboratory Parameter Value
Number of Participant With Any Clinically Relevant Urinalysis Parameter Value
primary_outcome.description: Clinical relevance was determined by the investigator.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Clinically Significant Electrocardiogram Findings
primary_outcome.time_frame: From signing of informed consent up to Day 15
primary_outcome.description: Clinical significance was determined by the investigator.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Clinically Significant Physical Examination Findings
primary_outcome.time_frame: From signing of informed consent up to Day 15
primary_outcome.description: Clinical significance was determined by the investigator.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Clinically Significant Vital Sign Findings
primary_outcome.time_frame: From signing of informed consent up to Day 15
primary_outcome.description: Clinical significance was determined by the investigator.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Free of Clinical Spasms
secondary_outcome.description: Clinical spasms were determined by video-electroencephalography (VEEG) for at least 8 hours and up to 24 hours.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants Free of Clinical Spasms
secondary_outcome.description: Clinical spasms were determined by VEEG for at least 8 hours and up to 24 hours.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Resolution of Hypsarrhythmia
secondary_outcome.description: Resolution of hypsarrhythmia was determined by VEEG for at least 8 hours and up to 24 hours.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Resolution of Hypsarrhythmia
secondary_outcome.description: Resolution of hypsarrhythmia was determined by VEEG for at least 8 hours and up to 24 hours.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Experiencing Spasms and Seizures by Subtype
secondary_outcome.description: Caregivers recorded the participant's spasms and seizures by category in a daily diary. Subtypes of spasms and seizures included: clonic, tonic-clonic, myoclonic, focal, and absence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Average Time to Cessation of Spasms
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 to start of Open-label Extension (OLE) Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Analysis could not be conducted for this outcome measure because the study met No Go Criteria. The Pilot Phase concluded after 9 participants completed treatment and demonstrated continued hypsarrhythmia and spasms on follow-up VEEG. The Pivotal Phase was not initiated; however, participants completing the Pilot Phase could roll into the Open Label Extension Phase (NCT02954887) for up to 1 year.

secondary_outcome.measure: Caregiver Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC)
secondary_outcome.description: The CGIC is a single-question assessment completed by the caregiver. The question assessed the status of the participant's condition since treatment start. The caregiver provided a rating on a 7-point scale from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).

The PGIC is a single-question assessment completed by the investigator. The question assesses the status of the participant's condition since treatment start. The investigator provided a rating on a 7-point scale from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).
A responder is defined as a participant experiencing a resolution of hypsarrhythmia and free of spasms. Testing for responders was conducted by VEEG for at least 8 hours and up to 24 hours.
A responder is defined as a participant experiencing a resolution of hypsarrhythmia and free of spasms. Testing for responders was conducted by VEEG for at least 8 hours and up to 24 hours.

arm_group.description: Administered orally, titrating to a target dose of 40 mg/kg/day. Participants continue at the target dose, or the highest tolerated dose up to the target dose, for the remainder of the 2-week treatment period.

intervention.description: Clear, colorless to yellow solution containing cannabidiol dissolved in the excipients sesame oil and anhydrous ethanol with added sweetener (sucralose) and strawberry flavoring.

criteria.textblock:
Key Inclusion Criteria:
- Participant is aged 6- 24 months (inclusive) in the first cohort or aged 1-24 months (inclusive) in the second cohort, at the time of consent.
- Participant is diagnosed with IS and has failed to respond adequately following treatment with 1 or more approved IS therapies.
- To be considered hypsarrhythmia, as defined for use in the study, the electroencephalography (EEG) background must be slowed and have multifocal spikes. In addition, it must be either high voltage (above 300 ÂµV) or have electrodecrement/discontinuity.
Key Exclusion Criteria:
- Participant is currently taking or has taken clobazam or any mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor within the 2 weeks prior to the screening visit.
- Participant has a QT interval, corrected for heart rate with Bazett's formula (QTcB), of 460 msec or greater on ECG.
- Participant's caregiver is currently giving or has given recreational or medicinal cannabis, or synthetic cannabinoid-based medications, within the 1 month prior to the screening visit.
- Participant's caregiver is unwilling to abstain from giving the participant (including the participant's mother abstaining themselves, if breastfeeding)recreational or medicinal cannabis, or synthetic cannabinoid-based medications (other than the study drug) during the trial.
- Participant has any known or suspected hypersensitivity to cannabinoids or any of the excipients of the study drug, such as sesame oil.
- Participant has significantly impaired hepatic function at the screening visit.
- Participant has received an investigational medicinal product as part of a clinical trial within a minimum of 5 half-lives prior to the screening visit.

facility.name: The Childrens Hospital of San Antonio

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were screened to assess their eligibility to enter the trial within 7 days prior to the first dose administration.

group.title: Cohort 1: GWP42003-P OS
group.description: Participants 6 months to 24 months of age received GWP42003-P oral solution (OS) for 14 days. Starting on Day 1 and over the course of 4 days, participants titrated up to a tolerable dose, not to exceed the target dose of 40 milligrams per kilograms per day (mg/kg/day) of GWP42003-P.

group.title: Cohort 2: GWP42003-P OS
group.description: Participants 1 month to 24 months of age received GWP42003-P OS for 14 days. Starting on Day 1 and over the course of 4 days, participants titrated up to a tolerable dose, not to exceed the target dose of 40 mg/kg/day of GWP42003-P.

outcome.title: Average Time to Cessation of Spasms
outcome.description: Analysis could not be conducted for this outcome measure because the study met No Go Criteria. The Pilot Phase concluded after 9 participants completed treatment and demonstrated continued hypsarrhythmia and spasms on follow-up VEEG. The Pivotal Phase was not initiated; however, participants completing the Pilot Phase could roll into the Open Label Extension Phase (NCT02954887) for up to 1 year.

reported_events.time_frame: From signing of informed consent up to Day 15
reported_events.desc: Treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) were collected in members of the Safety Population, comprised of all participants who received at least 1 dose of GWP42003-P. TEAEs are defined as all adverse events not present prior to the first investigational medicinal product (IMP) or placebo administration or any event already present that worsened in severity or frequency following IMP.

group.title: GWP42003-P OS
group.description: Participants received GWP42003-P oral solution (OS) for 14 days. Starting on Day 1 and over the course of 4 days, participants titrated up to a tolerable dose, not to exceed the target dose of 40 mg/kg/day of GWP42003-P.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This study met No Go Criteria. The Pilot Phase concluded after 9 participants completed treatment, and the Pivotal Phase was not initiated. Participants completing the Pilot Phase could roll into the Open Label Extension Phase for up to 1 year.
